Over 21,000 self-certification applications

22/11/2022

Nouse can reveal that in the first two terms of 2022, over 21,000 self-certification applications were processed

Image by Luke Snell

By Hannah Boyle

A Nouse freedom of Information request has revealed that there were approximately 21,080 applications for assessment extension through the self-certification process from January 2022 up until the end of the 2021/22 academic year.

The figure includes applications by over 2,500 postgraduate students between 4 January 2022 and 28 April 2022. This figure equates to 46 percent of postgraduate students making use of the scheme, while 26 percent of undergraduate students applied for self-certification within the same time frame.

The popularity of the scheme doesnâ€™t come as a surprise, as it allowed students to gain a four-dayÂ extension to submit the relevant assignment without having to supply additional evidence to the corresponding department. The scheme only applied to coursework pieces, such as essays, and not examinations, however the scheme remained popular with students.

The scheme was implemented to combat issues with short-term illness caused by Covid-19, however further arguments in favour of the scheme focused on students who may be experiencing technology failure and complexity in personal circumstances.

The figures come as the University announces a new policy to limit the number of self-certification applications to only three applications, per student, per year, any further extensions would require a student to submit evidence to their department. Students taking part in Postgraduate Research programmes and York Online programmes will not be able to use the scheme in its current form. As with the previous scheme, students can gain a four-day deadline to complete the work.

A student who used self-certification for past assessments said â€œit helped me manage my stress, and my deadlines, and allowed me some leeway to ensure my assessments were finished to the highest standard I could provide. It was easy to use and helped calm me during stressful exam periods and Iâ€™m really glad itâ€™s a support feature at the university.â€ Another student, studying a postgraduate course who used the scheme, said â€œitâ€™s good that the university has a system in place to help you if challenges come up which canâ€™t be avoided. I found it to be a positive thing to use when I needed it.â€

YUSU Sabbs, including President Pierrick Roger and Academic Officer Debayan Dey, wrote to the University Standing Committee on Assessment (SCA) asking them â€œto carefully consider the risks on student well-being of introducing restrictions on self-certification compared to the rather minor cost of self-certified extensions.â€

The letter continued to say â€œSelf-certification being restricted forces students into completing assessments that they may not be in the right mental state for and may cause them to panic, become more mentally distressed and potentially invoke a state of mental ill-health. This can be avoided, and has been throughout the last academic year for many students, by using the self-certification procedures that are currently in place. We encourage you to consult with our academic representative network to understand the impact of changes before proceeding.â€

Pierrick Roger later confirmed that YUSU have not received a response to their open letter, stating â€œSCA has decided to completely ignore objections from all Sabbatical Officers from both YUSU and the GSA.â€

In response to this article, a university spokesman said: â€œWe have listened carefully to the concerns of the GSA and YUSU but believe we would not be fulfilling our duty to look after the welfare of our students if we al-lowed individuals to create an unman-ageable assessment load for themselves in the summer.

â€œExtensions and deferrals are not without significant risk, and can increase, rather than solve, problems of student anxiety and stress during peak periods of assessment. If a student is unable to pass the assessment in the late summer period, they would need to take a full year off in order to complete the assessment or resit.

â€œIf a student is consistently struggling to meet deadlines for any reason, we urge them to contact their department so that we can put appropriate support in place for them as soon as possible.
